conclusion: Determine the time at which the laser beam emerges from the arc surface ABC.
The semi-cylindrical brick has a radius r, and the laser beam moves from point A to point C along the diameter AC.
The center of the semi-circle is point O.
Initially, the laser beam hits point A.
The laser beam travels along the straight line AC at a uniform speed v.
The laser will emerge from the arc surface ABC when the angle of incidence equals the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The critical angle θc is given by θc = arcsin(1/n).
The laser beam will emerge when it reaches the point on the arc where the angle between the radius and the vertical is θc.
The angle θ from the vertical at which the beam emerges is θc.
The arc length from A to the point of emergence is calculated using the angle θc: Arc length = r * θc.
The time t taken to reach the point of emergence is given by the distance traveled along AC divided by the speed v: t = (r * θc) / v.
Substitute the expression for θc: t = (r * arcsin(1/n)) / v.
The moment when the light emerges from the arc surface ABC is t = (r * arcsin(1/n)) / v.
